The image is a scatter plot titled “Daily maximum temperatures in Seattle, 1979–2021”, depicting over four decades of climate data. Here’s an eloquent and insightful description of the visualization:

title: high-temperature
text:
Description of the Image
This scatter plot illustrates the daily maximum temperatures in Seattle across the years 1979 to 2021. The x-axis represents the day of the year (1 through 365), and the y-axis denotes the maximum daily temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, ranging approximately from 20°F to 120°F.
Each small gray dot corresponds to a single day’s maximum recorded temperature across this 43-year span, forming a seasonal arc that reflects Seattle’s annual temperature cycle:
Lower temperatures dominate the winter months (beginning and end of the year).
Higher temperatures cluster in the mid-year, peaking in summer (June to August).
At the center-top of the plot, three large red dots stand out significantly above the rest of the distribution. These represent the exceptionally hot temperatures recorded over a three-day period, annotated with the bold red label “Last 3 days.”
The visual starkly emphasizes the extreme heat anomaly, as those red points sit well above the typical range for that time of year — a powerful visual cue highlighting how rare and unprecedented these temperatures were compared to historical records.

title: About
text: This file shows historical temerature mape in Seattle from 1979-2021. The data, image and description is prepared with AI.
